channel.title: Comments on: There’s Always Something
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Tahir Khalid
item.dc:creator: Tahir Khalid
item.content:encoded:
This post applies to both SQL code and the strange gobbldy gook languages developers play with (stuff like C#, VB etc).

I am pretty sure I have got a whole shelf full of code that is ever evolving.

I like building up a collection of libraries and utility classes that I can use/reuse in my C# coding (a habit I picked up from my C programming days) and I often develop something new, get to about 90% completion and then put it away for ages only to come back 6 months later and either go:

Oh cool, did I do that?

or

OMG WTF, I better hide this before someone sees it!

As you said, it’s all part of the learning process and why I love doing what I do..The day I stop having fun and learning something new is the day I take up knitting.

item.title: By: Janice Lee
item.dc:creator: Janice Lee
item.content:encoded:
I have had to do this myself several times in the past. I always got a kick out of rewriting and finetuning code that wasn’t written by me. When it was *my* code though that I was asked to “improve” months after I had written it, there were voices in my head that literally wouldn’t let myself hear the end of it. ðŸ˜‰

Good post, thirster42, and good day indeed!

item.title: By: David Forck (thirster42)
item.dc:creator: David Forck (thirster42)
item.description: Thank you Denis. The main reasoning for updating the proc, to me, was the fact that the report that uses this proc is ran a lot each day, and reducing the footprint, even if it's just a little bit, is actually a pretty big change.
item.content:encoded: Thank you Denis. The main reasoning for updating the proc, to me, was the fact that the report that uses this proc is ran a lot each day, and reducing the footprint, even if it’s just a little bit, is actually a pretty big change.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
Awesome…good for you.

You know, if I had to look at code and rewrite stuff I wrote a while back I would be rewriting for a year ðŸ™‚

I do rewrite stuff if I see e performance benefit, for example we upgraded to SQL 2008 from 2000 and I now use the ranking functions for paging instead of the old ghetto subquery set rowcount method.

I also now use dates instead of datetime for when I only need dates.

Keep it up!
